comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: Clara Millington Dow (29 December 1883 - 26 March 1969) was an English operatic soprano of the early twentieth century. After a concert career, she appeared at the Savoy Theatre in the first repertory seasons of Gilbert and Sullivan operas mounted by the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company in 1906-09, under the direction of the author. She is remembered as one of the last principal sopranos personally trained by W. S. Gilbert at the Savoy. In between engagements with D'Oyly Carte, Dow performed in concerts and operetta. After her retirement from the professional stage, she directed amateur productions of the Savoy Operas until she was in her seventies. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clara_Dow

comment.author: 91829349@N00
comment._content: The caption says "Cora Dow" -- pharmacist and philanthropist. More than you ever wanted to know about her here: www.lloydlibrary.org/scholar/CoraDow%20final.pdf (There's a picture of her on p. 2 -- looks to be the same lady.)

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: In case that link doesn't work for someone, here's the article cite: Metta Lou Henderson and Dennis B. Worthen, "Cora Dow (1868-1915)--Pharmacist, Entrepreneur, Philanthropist," Pharmacy in History 46(3)(2004): 91-105. Interesting story!

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: At thevirtualdimemuseum.blogspot.com/2009/03/cora-dow-pharma... she is offered as a role model for young women. With another picture that matches this one. The Washington herald. (Washington, D.C.) 1906-1939, November 28, 1915, FEATURE SECTION, Image 24 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045433/1915-11-28/ed-... has a feature on her shortly after her 1915 death. The Seattle star. (Seattle, Wash.) 1899-1947, May 01, 1907, Last Edition, Image 7 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn87093407/1907-05-01/ed-... has a picture of her in the same necklace/choker.

comment._content: There's a sad look there....in the eyes(I know they couldn't smile because how long the Dags took)but the eyes....haunting

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Photographers pretty much stopped making "Dags" (Daguerreotypes) by 1860. In 1914, portraits, if properly lighted, could be made instantaneously.
